gwt.ns.transforms.client
Class Matrix4x4

java.lang.Object
  gwt.ns.transforms.client.Matrix4x4

public class Matrix4x4
extends java.lang.Object

4x4 matrix for representation of affine transformations in three dimensions (using homogeneous coordinates). Matrix is "column-major," meaning that, in the multiplication of a series of transforms, the first applied matrix is on the far right. The translation values are found in column four.

All methods have been optimized, but full multiplies and inversions still incur relatively heavy performance costs. If possible, tend toward the problem specific. For example, use matrix.rotateX(angle) instead of matrix.multiply(rotationMatrix), or note that the transpose of an orthonormal matrix is also its inverse, so does not require a full inverse calculation.

Method Detail

copy

public void copy(Matrix4x4 src)
Sets this matrix to the specified transform.

Parameters:
src - The transform to be copied.

inverse

public void inverse(Matrix4x4 dest)
Calculates the inverse of this matrix, if it exists, and stores it in dest. This is an intensive calculation and should be avoided if possible. If this matrix is orthonormal, try inverseOrthonormalAffine(Matrix4x4).

Implementation from David Eberly's "The Laplace Expansion Theorem: Computing the Determinants and Inverses of Matrices".

Parameters:
dest - The destination of the inverse.
See Also:
"The Laplace Expansion Theorem: Computing the Determinants and Inverses of Matrices"

inverseOrthonormalAffine

public void inverseOrthonormalAffine(Matrix4x4 dest)
Calculates the inverse of this matrix, assuming this is an orthonormal matrix + translation (e.g. concatenation of rotations and translations). Any perspective projection will likely have an adverse effect on the result. Incredibly fast compared to a full inverse.

Parameters:
dest - The destination of the inverse.

multiply

public void multiply(Matrix4x4 local)
Applies a transform in local coordinates to this matrix. Essentially, this=this*local.

Parameters:
local - The transform to apply.

multiply

public void multiply(Matrix4x4 view,
                     Matrix4x4 local)
Sets this matrix equal to view multiplied by local, with view on the left and local on the right. This matrix is overwritten in process of multiplication, so should not itself be view or local.

Note: this is the most efficient of the multiply methods, because no copy is required, but use the transformation-specific methods if at all possible. They are each optimized for their particular operation, which can result in needing only a small fraction of the calculations needed for this general method.

this = view*local

Parameters:
view - left-hand matrix
local - right-hand matrix

multiplyView

public void multiplyView(Matrix4x4 view)
Applies a transform in view coordinates to this matrix. 
this=view*this

Parameters:
view - The transform to apply

scale

public void scale(double sx,
                  double sy)
Scales the matrix by the given vector in local coordinates. In 2-space, the vector is [sx, sy]. In 3, it is [sx, sy, 1].

Parameters:
sx - The x coordinate of the scale vector
sy - The y coordinate of the scale vector

transformX

public double transformX(double x,
                         double y,
                         double z,
                         double w)
Returns the x-component of the image of point (x, y, z, w) under the current transform. A w-value of 1 is generally used for points, 0 for vectors.

Parameters:
x - The x coordinate of point to transform
y - The y coordinate of point to transform
z - The z coordinate of point to transform
w - The w coordinate of point to transform
Returns:
The x coordinate of the transformed point

Parameters:

w - The w coordinate of point to transform
